title: Polygons & Quadrilaterals
description: Derive and apply the polygon interior angle sum formula, explore the quadrilateral hierarchy (parallelogram, rectangle, rhombus, square), and apply properties of trapezoids and kites.
goals: Find the sum of interior and exterior angles of any polygon using (n-2)·180°
Identify and apply properties of parallelograms, rectangles, rhombi, and squares
Use properties of quadrilaterals to write proofs
Apply properties of trapezoids and kites
instructionalStrategy: Derive the polygon angle sum formula by triangulating from one vertex—students see why (n-2) works.
Build the quadrilateral hierarchy as a family tree: quadrilateral → parallelogram → rectangle/rhombus → square.
Every property of a parent in the hierarchy is inherited by children—a square has ALL properties of a parallelogram, rectangle, AND rhombus.
Use coordinate geometry to verify quadrilateral properties (slopes for parallel sides, distance for congruent sides).

scaffold.title: Polygon Interior and Exterior Angle Sums
scaffold.text:
The **Polygon Interior Angle Sum Theorem** gives us a formula for the total degrees inside any convex polygon:

**Sum of interior angles = (n - 2) × 180°**

where n = number of sides.

**Why does this work?** From one vertex, you can draw diagonals to create (n - 2) triangles. Each triangle has 180°, so the total is (n - 2) × 180°.

Examples:
• Triangle (n=3): (3-2) × 180° = 180°
• Quadrilateral (n=4): (4-2) × 180° = 360°
• Pentagon (n=5): (5-2) × 180° = 540°
• Hexagon (n=6): (6-2) × 180° = 720°

For a **regular polygon** (all sides and angles equal), each angle = (n-2) × 180° / n.

**Exterior Angle Sum:** The sum of exterior angles of ANY convex polygon is always **360°**. For a regular polygon, each exterior angle = 360° / n.
scaffold.initialPrompt: A stop sign is a regular octagon (8 sides). Can you calculate the sum of its interior angles and the measure of each individual angle?

scaffold.title: I-Do: Polygon Angle Calculations

examples.problem: Find the sum of interior angles of a decagon (10 sides) and the measure of each interior angle if it is regular.
examples.solution:
Sum of interior angles: (n-2) × 180° = (10-2) × 180° = 8 × 180° = **1440°**

Each angle of a regular decagon: 1440° ÷ 10 = **144°**

Exterior angle at each vertex: 180° - 144° = 36°. Check: 36° × 10 = 360° ✓

examples.problem: The interior angles of a polygon sum to 2340°. How many sides does the polygon have?
Each interior angle of a regular polygon measures 150°. Find the number of sides and the sum of all interior angles.
examples.solution:
Each exterior angle = 180° - 150° = 30°
n = 360° ÷ 30° = **12 sides** (a regular dodecagon)

Sum = (12-2) × 180° = 10 × 180° = **1800°**
Verify: 1800° ÷ 12 = 150° per angle ✓

scaffold.initialPrompt: The exterior angles always sum to 360°, no matter how many sides. Why do you think that's true? Think about walking around the outside of the shape.

scaffold.title: The Quadrilateral Family Hierarchy
scaffold.text:
**The Quadrilateral Family** (each type inherits all properties of its parent):

**Parallelogram** — both pairs of opposite sides parallel:
• Opposite sides are congruent
• Opposite angles are congruent
• Consecutive angles are supplementary
• Diagonals bisect each other

**Rectangle** — parallelogram with 4 right angles:
• All parallelogram properties PLUS
• Diagonals are congruent

**Rhombus** — parallelogram with 4 congruent sides:
• All parallelogram properties PLUS
• Diagonals are perpendicular
• Diagonals bisect the angles

**Square** — a rectangle AND a rhombus:
• ALL properties of parallelogram, rectangle, AND rhombus
scaffold.initialPrompt: Is every square a rectangle? Is every rectangle a square? Explain the difference.

scaffold.title: I-Do: Quadrilateral Property Applications

examples.problem: In parallelogram ABCD, ∠A = (3x + 10)° and ∠B = (5x - 30)°. Find all four angles.
In rectangle EFGH, the diagonals intersect at M. If EG = 26, find EM, MG, and FH.
examples.solution:
Rectangle diagonals bisect each other:
EM = MG = 26 ÷ 2 = **13**

Rectangle diagonals are congruent:
FH = EG = **26**

So FM = MH = 13 as well.

examples.problem: Rhombus JKLM has ∠J = 60° and each side = 10. Find all angles and both diagonal lengths.
examples.solution:
Opposite angles: ∠L = ∠J = **60°**. Consecutive supplementary: ∠K = ∠M = **120°**.

Diagonals bisect angles and are perpendicular. Let O be the intersection.
In right triangle JOK: ∠OJK = 60°/2 = 30°, JK = 10 (hypotenuse of the right triangle at O).

This is a 30-60-90 triangle:
JO = 10 × cos(30°) = 10 × (√3/2) = 5√3
KO = 10 × sin(30°) = 10 × (1/2) = 5

Diagonals: JL = 2 × 5√3 = **10√3 ≈ 17.3**, KM = 2 × 5 = **10**
Verify: (5√3)² + 5² = 75 + 25 = 100 = 10² ✓

scaffold.title: Trapezoids and Kites
scaffold.text:
**Trapezoids** have exactly one pair of parallel sides (called **bases**). The non-parallel sides are called **legs**.

**Isosceles Trapezoid** (congruent legs):
• Base angles are congruent
• Diagonals are congruent
• Legs are congruent
• Same-side angles between a base and leg are supplementary

**Midsegment of a Trapezoid:**
The segment connecting the midpoints of the legs is called the midsegment. Its length = (base₁ + base₂) / 2 (the average of the two bases).

**Kites** have two pairs of consecutive congruent sides (not opposite):
• One pair of opposite angles is congruent (between the non-equal sides)
• Diagonals are perpendicular
• One diagonal bisects the other
• Area = (d₁ × d₂) / 2
scaffold.initialPrompt: A trapezoid has bases of 8 and 14. What is the length of the midsegment? Can you see why it's called the 'average' of the bases?

scaffold.title: I-Do: Trapezoid and Kite Calculations

examples.problem: A trapezoid has bases of 14 and 22. Find the length of the midsegment.
examples.solution:
Midsegment = (base₁ + base₂) / 2 = (14 + 22) / 2 = 36 / 2 = **18**

The midsegment is always parallel to both bases and exactly halfway between them.

examples.problem: In isosceles trapezoid ABCD, ∠A = (4x + 10)° and ∠D = (8x - 10)°, where AB ∥ DC. Find x and all four angle measures.
examples.solution:
In a trapezoid with AB ∥ DC, angles A and D are same-side interior angles (supplementary):
(4x + 10) + (8x - 10) = 180
12x = 180 → x = 15

∠A = 4(15) + 10 = **70°**, ∠D = 8(15) - 10 = **110°**
Isosceles: ∠B = ∠A = **70°**, ∠C = ∠D = **110°**

Check: 70 + 70 + 110 + 110 = 360° ✓

examples.problem: Kite WXYZ has diagonals WY = 16 and XZ = 12, with the diagonals perpendicular. Find the area of the kite.
examples.solution:
Area of a kite = (d₁ × d₂) / 2
Area = (16 × 12) / 2 = 192 / 2 = **96 square units**

This works because the kite can be split into 4 right triangles by its diagonals.

problems.question: Is a square always a rhombus? Is a rhombus always a square? Explain.
problems.answer: Yes, a square is always a rhombus (4 congruent sides). No, a rhombus is not always a square—it doesn't require right angles.
hints: A square has 4 congruent sides (rhombus) AND 4 right angles (rectangle). A rhombus only needs 4 congruent sides.
